channel.title: What the hell is wrong with my code :(

item.title: What the hell is wrong with my code :(
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The compiler optimizes the imports at compile-time anyway, and therefore never actually imports more than you need. Therefore speed is not affected at runtime or compile-time. However proper coding practice indicates that you should explicitly import only what you need so that later programmers can easily see what you used or didn’t use.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:13, topic:122808”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=172539.msg1606772#msg1606772 date=1184738364]

import java.util.Scanner; // using * is bad programming practice

no its not… wut if he needs more than just that util? do you want him to make millions of import statements?

not trying to be rude though… but did you compile that?
[/quote]It takes what…? Not even a little bit of time on compiling if you import an entire directory.

i guess im slow but, what did u mean by that?[/quote]

He means that you can import four classes or its entire library and it will take hardly an time extra, or at least that you would notice.

item.title: What the hell is wrong with my code :(
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“blah bah7, post:5, topic:122808”][quote author=pizza pie link=topic=172539.msg1594372#msg1594372 date=1184371446]

import java.util.Scanner; // using * is bad programming practice

no its not… wut if he needs more than just that util? do you want him to make millions of import statements?

not trying to be rude though… but did you compile that?
[/quote]

it is if you only have one statement, if you have like ten import statements go ahead and use *, if you just have one, dont[/quote]

Using the asterisk wildcard tells the compiler to find all the imports in that package that your program uses. If you decompile a java program after compiling it, you will see it does not compile it with the asterisk. It makes all the imports for each class that you need importing. So if you use, I would personally say, three or more imports from the same libary, an asterisk helps make the imports neater.

Pezlam, try the follow code instead:

import java.util.*;

public class ServerSwitch
{
	private String[] servers = { "jolt2.mehmeh.com", "jolt4.mehmeh.com", "jolt5.mehmeh.com" };

	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		try
		{
			Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
			int intInput = Integer.parseInt(input.nextLine());
			System.out.println("Selected Server: " + servers[intInput + 1];
		}
		catch (NumberFormatException e) { System.out.println("You can only enter in numbers."); }
	}
}

Read full topic

item.title: What the hell is wrong with my code :(
item.dc:creator: @blah_bah7 blah bah7
item.description:
@blah_bah7 wrote:

[code]import java.util.Scanner; // using * is bad programming practice
import static java.lang.System.out;

class yeee{ //wtf is yeee?

public static void main(String args[]) {

//you forgot (String args[]) and the {
//you dont neccecarily need the String args[], that is for program input

	String servers[] = { "jolt3.mehmeh.com",
	     		"jolt4.mehmeh.com",
	     		"jolt5.mehmeh.com" };

	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
	int intInput = -1;

	if (!input.hasNextInt()) {

	}

	intInput = input.nextInt();

	if ((intInput > (servers.length - 1)) || (intInput < 0))
	{


	String selectedServer = servers[intInput];

	out.println(" + selectedServer + ");

// are you trying to show the server they selected, if so use this: out.println(selectedServer)
}
}
}[/code]

if you dont want to use it, just put

that should work, i think ur finished

item.title: What the hell is wrong with my code :(
item.dc:creator: @Pezlam Pezlam
item.description:
@Pezlam wrote:

ok im making a server switcher basically … and this is what i have at the moment … obviously there will be more to it … but i cant get it to compile to test if it will System.out the right server when i pick it. :

import java.util.*;

class yeee{

public static void main

String[] servers = { "jolt3.mehmeh.com",
		     "jolt4.mehmeh.com",
		     "jolt5.mehmeh.com" };

Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
int intInput = -1;

if (!input.hasNextInt()) {

}

intInput = input.nextInt();

if (intInput > servers.length - 1 || intInput < 0)
{


String selectedServer = servers[intInput];

System.out.println(" + selectedServer + ");
   }
}

and this is what i get 

yeee.java:7: '(' expected
String[] servers = { "jolt3.mehmeh.com",
^
yeee.java:14: illegal start of type
if (!input.hasNextInt()) {
^
yeee.java:14: <identifier> expected
if (!input.hasNextInt()) {
                     ^
yeee.java:14: ';' expected
if (!input.hasNextInt()) {
                       ^
yeee.java:18: <identifier> expected
intInput = input.nextInt();
        ^
yeee.java:20: illegal start of type
if (intInput > servers.length - 1 || intInput < 0)
^
yeee.java:20: <identifier> expected
if (intInput > servers.length - 1 || intInput < 0)
            ^
yeee.java:20: <identifier> expected
if (intInput > servers.length - 1 || intInput < 0)
                             ^
yeee.java:20: illegal start of type
if (intInput > servers.length - 1 || intInput < 0)
                                                ^
9 errors
Press any key to continue . . .

any help would at this moment would obviously be great … since im getting slightly pissed :@

Read full topic
